items.title: Default Apps of 2023
items.content_html:
All of a sudden it is all over my RSS feeds, people blogging about the default apps they use for most of their online activities. OK, so yeah… this is apparently a thing and of course I can’t be left behind! Ever since the early days of blogging (The shrouded secrets of the past, lores of yore…) these list have existed and it’s always great fun to peruse through them. Robb Knight is collecting a list of those who have participated.

Here are my defaults in 2023. Personal and professional separated where necessary. I also added one aspirational app for 2024…

  • Mail Client - Fastmail (personal)/Gmail (work)
  • Mail Server - Fastmail (personal)/Gmail (work)
  • Notes - Obsidian
  • To-Do - Reminders (personal)/Todoist (work)
  • iPhone Photo Shooting - default app or Halide
  • Photo Management - iPhotos
  • Calendar - Fastmail (personal)/Google Calendar (work)
  • Cloud File Storage - iCloud & Stack
  • RSS - BazQux & Fiery Feeds
  • Contacts - Fastmail
  • Browser - Brave
  • Chat - Signal & Whatsapp (personal) / Slack (work)
  • Bookmarks - Brave & Drafts
  • Read It Later - Readwise & Drafts
  • Word Processing - Obsidian (personal)/Google Docs (work)
  • Spreadsheets - Google Sheets
  • Presentations - Keynote
  • Shopping Lists - Pen and paper
  • Meal Planning - Pen and paper
  • Budgeting and Personal Finance - MijnGeldzaken.nl (roughly translates to My Moneystuff)
  • Music - Spotify
  • Password Management - 1Password
  • Blogging - Drafts, Micro.blog, WordPress
  • Clipboard Manager - Paste
  • Terminal - iTerm with zsh
  • Journaling - Day One
  • Automation - Keyboard Maestro
  • Launcher - Raycast
  • Searchengine - DuckDuckGo
  • Aspirational app for 2024 - Emacs
items.content_text:
All of a sudden it is all over my RSS feeds, people blogging about the default apps they use for most of their online activities.  OK, so yeah... this is apparently a _thing_ and of course I can't be left behind! Ever since the early days of blogging (The shrouded secrets of the past, lores of yore...) these list have existed and it's always great fun to peruse through them. [Robb Knight](https://defaults.rknight.me/) is collecting a list of those who have participated.

Here are my defaults  in 2023. Personal and professional separated where necessary. I also added one aspirational app for 2024...


- Mail Client - Fastmail (personal)/Gmail (work)
- Mail Server - Fastmail (personal)/Gmail (work)
- Notes - Obsidian
- To-Do - Reminders (personal)/Todoist (work)
- iPhone Photo Shooting - default app or [Halide](https://halide.cam/)
- Photo Management - iPhotos
- Calendar - Fastmail (personal)/Google Calendar (work)
- Cloud File Storage - iCloud & Stack
- RSS - [BazQux](https://bazqux.com/) & [Fiery Feeds](https://voidstern.net/fiery-feeds)
- Contacts - Fastmail
- Browser - Brave
- Chat - Signal & Whatsapp (personal) / Slack (work)
- Bookmarks - Brave & [Drafts](https://getdrafts.com/)
- Read It Later - Readwise & Drafts
- Word Processing - Obsidian (personal)/Google Docs (work)
- Spreadsheets - Google Sheets
- Presentations - Keynote
- Shopping Lists - Pen and paper
- Meal Planning - Pen and paper
- Budgeting and Personal Finance - MijnGeldzaken.nl (roughly translates to My Moneystuff)
- Music - Spotify
- Password Management - 1Password
- Blogging - Drafts, Micro.blog, WordPress
- Clipboard Manager - Paste
- Terminal - iTerm with zsh
- Journaling - Day One
- Automation - Keyboard Maestro
- Launcher - Raycast
- Searchengine - DuckDuckGo
- Aspirational app for 2024 - Emacs

items.content_html: First of 5 days off. No big plans, taking some rest and see what we want and can do at the end of the year.
items.content_text: First of 5 days off. No big plans, taking some rest and see what we want and can do at the end of the year.

items.content_html: Browsing in my RSS feeds and I see this post by @jack why he loves orgmode for archiving todos. I can relate. Not that I use orgmode. I try every now and then but I get into config-rabbitholes really quick. But since I’m reviewing several parts of my online life, why not give it a go again?
items.content_text: Browsing in my RSS feeds and I see this post by [@jack](https://micro.blog/jack) [why he loves orgmode for archiving todos](https://rudimentarylathe.org/2023/11/reason-i-love-org-mode-no-257-archiving-todos/). I can relate. Not that I use orgmode. I try every now and then but I get into config-rabbitholes really quick. But since I’m reviewing several parts of my online life, why not give it a go again?

items.content_html: Trying @gluon, @icro and the official Micro.blog iOS app to see what sticks for me in both reading and writing. Even though I can also use Drafts as my main canvas.

items.content_html:
Finished reading: With the Light: Raising an Autistic Child (With the Light, #1) by Keiko Tobe 📚

I read this first chapter of the extended manga series some time ago. The story still touches me, about a young family in modern Japan raising a child with autism. In a society where there is little support for autism. The mother does everything possible to give her son a good upbringing and education. There is much ignorance in her environment around autism. Slowly, she meets more like-minded people who accept her son as he is.

I once found the complete series in a Manga and Anime exhibition in our public library. You can see the size of each volume on the picture below. This exhibition was organized with a local Manga shop who, as I just found out, have gone out of business in 2022.

More about the series can be found on WikiWand
items.content_text: Finished reading: [With the Light: Raising an Autistic Child (With the Light, #1)](https://micro.blog/books/9780759523562) by Keiko Tobe 📚 I read this first chapter of the extended manga series some time ago. The story still touches me, about a young family in modern Japan raising a child with autism. In a society where there is little support for autism. The mother does everything possible to give her son a good upbringing and education. There is much ignorance in her environment around autism. Slowly, she meets more like-minded people who accept her son as he is. I once found the complete series in a Manga and Anime exhibition in our public library. You can see the size of each volume on the picture below. This exhibition was organized with a local Manga shop who, as I [just found out](https://www.mangakissa.nl/nieuws/2022/10/19/locatie-pauwstraat-permanent-gesloten-per-1-november), have gone out of business in 2022. More about the series can be found on [WikiWand](https://www.wikiwand.com/en/With_the_Light)

items.content_html: I’m currently rolling my own solution to have tagged links in Pinboard sent periodically to my Jekyll blog as an individual article in a specific template. I’m now wrapping my head around whether I should save these RSS feeditems as array, object or JSON as a buffer. Learning to program is hard! Lots of trial and error but the endresult is very gratifying. It feels good you can make something to scratch your own itch instead of looking for 3rd party solutions.
items.content_text:
I'm currently rolling my own solution to have tagged links in [Pinboard](pinboard.in) sent periodically to my Jekyll blog as an individual article in a specific template.

I'm now wrapping my head around whether I should save these RSS feeditems as array, object or JSON as a buffer.

Learning to program is hard! Lots of trial and error but the endresult is very gratifying. It feels good you can make something to scratch your own itch instead of looking for 3rd party solutions.

items.content_html: I am searching on the internets for some solutions on how to include a searchbar and resultspage on my Github-pages flavored Jekyll site. What are the recommendations from the Microblog community on this? lunr.js? Super-search? Simple-jekyll-search?

items.content_html: We just finished our demo/livingroom in the office. We now have various smart home devices we can hook up to our Olisto app to test and demo. Of course I had to make sure there are comfy chairs. Here’s me working hard in our nice IKEA lounge chair. Love this place.

items.content_html:
I like this. Too many great quotes and ideas on blogging and selfpublishing to choose from. So I pick this one:

“We need to switch mode from passive to active, from consuming to creating. Start sowing seeds.”

Take the Power Back – iA
items.content_text:
I like this. Too many great quotes and ideas on blogging and selfpublishing to choose from. So I pick this one:

>“We need to switch mode from passive to active, from consuming to creating. Start sowing seeds.”

 [Take the Power Back – iA](https://ia.net/topics/take-the-power-back/)

items.content_html:
Twitter has their suggested users you might follow, Instagram has the list of interesting people/hashtags, Facebook just looks in your brain to see who you might know and Microblog has Discover.

Mastodon doesn’t have this and I miss it. I need some inspiration thrown at my feet.
items.content_text:
Twitter has their suggested users you might follow, Instagram has the list of interesting people/hashtags, Facebook just looks in your brain to see who you might know and Microblog has Discover.

Mastodon doesn’t have this and I miss it. I need some inspiration thrown at my feet.

items.content_html: Lately I’ve been deep in the Internet History Podcast from Brian McCullough. Great episodes ranging from the start of Netscape to Justin Hall as the “first” blogger. Totally love the indievibe we had back then. Find it near a podcast-shop near you!

items.content_html: Another project to find out: When my site gets updated by Ownyourgram, it’s a different version then my local version. I have my own workflow that doesn’t really check to get the latest version first from Github. Is there a way to check this before git push without having to think about fetch and pull?
items.content_text: Another project to find out: When my site gets updated by Ownyourgram, it's a different version then my local version. I have my own workflow that doesn't really check to get the latest version first from Github. Is there a way to check this before `git push` without having to think about fetch and pull?

items.content_html: I am looking for some help with micropub endpoints and OwnYourGram. I use this script on Github to have my own endpoint on my site. But now Instagram posts are posted to my Master branch and not to GH-Pages. Now what?
items.content_text: I am looking for some help with micropub endpoints and OwnYourGram. I use [this script](https://github.com/voxpelli/webpage-micropub-to-github) on Github to have my own endpoint on my site. But now Instagram posts are posted to my Master branch and not to GH-Pages. Now what?

items.content_html: Well…it turns out I just have to question this stuff, start over again and all of a sudden it works. A combination of Bridgy and webmention.herokuapp.com seems to work. I still need to style everything but the basics work. Not quite sure how but hey…
items.content_text: Well...it turns out I just have to question this stuff, start over again and all of a sudden it works. A combination of Bridgy and [webmention.herokuapp.com](https://webmention.herokuapp.com/) seems to work. I still need to style everything but the basics work. Not quite sure *how* but hey...

items.content_html: Webmentions. I have no idea where to start. I would like to have them on my site (runs on GH pages) instead of Disqus but I can’t figure what steps to take. I check out Bridgy, webmention.io, the jekyll plugin. But I can’t figure it out. I need a Webmention For Dummies!

items.content_html: Had quite the codefight last night (look at me all rhyming and stuff!) to try a new Jekyll theme. I ended up reading up on Git, Ruby, Bundle and Gem. It’s nice to DIY but it still so far away from hitting it the big league. And I still don’t have a new theme.
items.content_text: Had quite the codefight last night (look at me all rhyming and stuff!) to try a new Jekyll theme. I ended up reading up on Git, Ruby, Bundle and Gem. It's nice to DIY but it still so far away from hitting it the big league. And I still don't have a new theme.

items.title: My Sunday is a funday already!
items.content_html:
This Sunday is off to a good start. Already wrote my weekly digest of interesting links I found and my review of the Jim and Andy documentary on Netflix got retweeted by Netflix. Silo’s be damned, it still feels good!

Links are all in Dutch! 🗞 Weekly “leesmap” 🎬 Jim and Andy - The great beyond review
items.content_text:
This Sunday is off to a good start. Already wrote my weekly digest of interesting links I found and my review of the Jim and Andy documentary on Netflix got retweeted by Netflix. Silo's be damned, it still feels good! 

Links are all in Dutch!
🗞 [Weekly "leesmap"](http://diggingthedigital.com/leesmap-week-47/)
🎬 [Jim and Andy - The great beyond review](http://diggingthedigital.com/Jim-en-Andy/)

items.content_html: What are your thoughts on webhosting? I currently host my blog at Github Pages which is quite alright. I’ve had some experiences with webhosting and VPS, somehow it can get a hassle with those. Hosting at Amazon? What are your ideas?
items.content_text: What are your thoughts on webhosting? I currently host my blog at Github Pages which is quite alright. I've had some experiences with webhosting and VPS, somehow it can get a hassle with those. Hosting at Amazon? What are your ideas?

items.content_html: Just to get a different perspective on another network then Twitter: What would be your definition of a blog? What elements would that definition hold? Is a blog pure txt/img? Is Instagram a blog? Snapchat? When does a blog become an online magazine?
items.content_text: Just to get a different perspective on another network then Twitter: What would be _your_ definition of a blog? What elements would that definition hold? Is a blog pure txt/img? Is Instagram a blog? Snapchat? When does a blog become an online magazine?

items.content_html:
I’ve come to the conclusion that I am of age to rather leave a good party early to hang out at home until late. Than stay at said party until late. I’d have my couch win over a barstool every time. I also have better beer at home.

Insert old-man-whining.gif

items.content_text: I truly worry more and more on the state of big networks like Facebook. Articles like [this](https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/oct/25/facebook-orwellian-journalists-democracy-guatemala-slovakia) in The Guardian  about the newsfeedtests if FB in countries are scary...

items.title: What's my usecase for Microblog?
items.content_html:
With one day left in my trial account for Micro.blog I need to figure out what my usecase would be for this. I already have my own Jekyll-based site on diggingthedigital.com/. So another blog would be no use for me. I like some of the other conversations going on here but do I need to pay to see and participate in it? That is not quite clear to me. What would 5 dollar a month buy me that a free micro.blog account or my current blog doesn’t have? Is there a free micro.blog account? What does it have and what does it lack?

I have no problem to support indie developers but I already have some Patreon backings going for other developers. Choices. It all boils down to communicating what your service has to offer. Now it is unclear to me. The Help-page doesn’t give a hint either.

I think I just wait and see what happens.
items.content_text:
With one day left in my trial account for Micro.blog I need to figure out what my usecase would be for this. I already have my own Jekyll-based site on [diggingthedigital.com/.](http://diggingthedigital.com/.) So another blog would be no use for me. 
I like some of the other conversations going on here but do I need to pay to see and participate in it? That is not quite clear to me. 
What would 5 dollar a month buy me that a free micro.blog account or my current blog doesn't have? Is there a free micro.blog account? What does it have and what does it lack?

I have no problem to support indie developers but I already have some Patreon backings going for other developers. Choices. 
It all boils down to communicating what your service has to offer. Now it is unclear to me. The [Help-page](http://help.micro.blog/) doesn't give a hint either. 

I think I just wait and see what happens.

Time for Stranger Things!

items.content_html: I’m still figuring out how “owning your own content” helps me to engage on other networks. The startingpoint of IndieWeb always seems to be me starting something. Which is not always the case. I respond, retweet, favorite, build upon. How does that work? #IndieQuestions

items.content_html:
As a keyboard lover and support agent or our app, I’d love to have a better naming-scheme for the various emoji. Instead of typing :wink: and :crying: I’d rather have consistency such as :face-wink: and :face-crying:

But hey…that’s just me.
items.content_text:
As a keyboard lover and support agent or our app, I'd love to have a better naming-scheme for the various emoji. Instead of typing :wink: and :crying: I'd rather have consistency such as :face-wink: and :face-crying:

But hey...that's just me.

items.title: Everyone should blog?
items.content_html: According to Jack, we should. But meh… we had that hype 15 years ago. Too much hassle for a lot of people. They want to connect. They want a familiar place. Innovation and upgrades when they log in again. I know about the Indieweb. I’ve had my fair share of discussions on blogs vs social. But here’s the thing, times have changed. Mobile won. Facebook won. Instagram will win. For the coming decade. Something else comes along and that will win. Indie blogs will never win. And that’s a good thing.
items.content_text:
According to Jack, we [should](https://jack.baty.net/2017/i-just-want-everyone-to-start-blogging-again/). But meh... we had that hype 15 years ago. Too much hassle for a lot of people. They want to connect. They want a familiar place. Innovation and upgrades when they log in again. 
I know about the Indieweb. I’ve had my fair share of discussions on blogs vs social. But here’s the thing, times have changed. Mobile won. Facebook won. Instagram will win. For the coming decade. Something else comes along and that will win. Indie blogs will never win. And that’s a good thing.

items.content_html:
Sundays are good for catching up on my RSS-subscriptions (InoReader is my favorite reader of the week, all bow down to the OPML export options to migrate fast)

Since I work in the IoT/Smart home industry there’s new products and services popping up every other day it seems. Some of my favorites from this morning

  • Mycroft Open Source Home Assistant
  • BuddyGuard smart security
  • NBA Connected tech
  • Jawku Speed wristband for runners

There’s so much to invent in this world….
items.content_text:
Sundays are good for catching up on my RSS-subscriptions ([InoReader](https://www.inoreader.com) is my favorite reader of the week, all bow down to the OPML export options to migrate fast)

Since I work in the IoT/Smart home industry there's new products and services popping up every other day it seems. Some of my favorites from this morning

* [Mycroft Open Source Home Assistant](http://www.stephensonstrategies.com/mycroft-brings-open-source-revolution-to-home-assistants/)
* [BuddyGuard smart security](https://www.postscapes.com/pulse/smart-security-camera-maker-buddyguard-raises-4m/)
* [NBA Connected tech](https://www.wareable.com/wearable-tech/nba-court-ar-vr-smart-home-139)
* [Jawku Speed wristband for runners](https://www.wareable.com/sport/jawku-speed-wearable-wristband-5250)

There's so much to invent in this world....
